name: electricity production, hydro, run-of-river | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/8514/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kWh of electricity in a run-of-river power plant unit in Japan in 2012. Run-of-river power plants are hydro power plants without reservoirs. Depending on the net head of the power plant, high-pressure, medium-pressure and low-pressure systems can be distinguished. Low-pressure power plants including river power stations and canal power plants are very common; therefore these two types of run-of-river power stations are covered in the dataset. To some extent, high-pressure as well as medium-pressure run-of-river systems can be considered as reservoir power stations, e.g. as unit in plant groups that are dominated by storage power plants, but also include alpine run power stations.;LCI data are based on a representative sample of various types of power plants in Switzerland and Austria is taken into account. The calculations are based on the information and data of the following run-of-river power plants: Rupperswil-Auenstein (Baumann 1949), Wildegg-Brugg (NOK 1956), Birsfelden (Aegerter et al. 1954), Donaukraftwerk Greifenstein (Brux 1983; max. Leistung 237 MW) and Rheinkraftwerk Albbruck-Dogern (Radag 1979) as well as the new construction of the power plant Ruppoldingen. The determined specific data was then related to the entire power plant park of Switzerland with an annual net electricity output of 15484 GWh/a (BEW 2001a). Lifetime is assumed to be 80 years for the structural part (including cement, reinforcing steel, diesel, electricity, transportation and explosives) and 40 years for the rest of materials. The data refers to plant construction of a mix of types of dams built between 1945 and the beginning of the 1980s; therefore they might not be representative for more modern construction, for an individual type and for small-scale and smallest-scale plants.;Baumann J. (1949) Kraftwerk Rupperswil-Auenstein. Verlag Kraftwerk;Rupperswil-Auenstein AG, Rupperswil.;Nordostschweizerische Kraftwerke AG (NOK) (1956) Das Kraftwerk;Wildegg-Brugg. In: Schweizerische Bauzeitung, 74 (4), 47-52; 74 (5), 63-67; 74;(6), 83-88; 74 (7), 93-99; 74 (8), 111-116; 74 (10), 145-147; 74 (12), 167-172.;Aegerter A., Dr. Bosshardt O. (1954) Das Kraftwerk Birsfelden. In: Wasser- und;Energiewirtschaft, 46 (5-7), 165-176.;Brux G. (1983) Das Donaukraftwerk Greifenstein. In: Wasser, Energie, Luft, 75;(1-2), 11-13.;Radag A. (1979) 50 Jahre Rheinkraftwerk Albbruck-Dogern Aktiengesellschaft.;Waldshut/Rhein, 1929-1979.;Bundesamt für Energiewirtschaft (2001) Elektrizitatsstatistik 2000. Bern,;Schweiz.;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

From (potential) energy in water, entering the power plant and use of power plant infrastructure.

The activity ends with 1 kWh of high voltage electricity produced at the power plant and arrived at the busbar. 

The datasets includes the use of lubricant oil and the mass of water assing through the turbines.

The dataset doesn´t include detailed specifications about land use due to methodical issues. This information is only included via transformation and occuption of land and calculated with an simplified approach.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data represent the average of a characteristic sample of Swiss run-of-river hydropower plants.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Run-of-river power plants are hydro power plants without important reservoirs. Depending on the net head of the power plant, high-pressure, medium-pressure and low-pressure systems can be distinguished. Low-pressure power plants including river power stations and canal power plants are very common; therefore these two types of run-of-river power stations are covered in the dataset. To some extent, high-pressure as well as medium-pressure run-of-river systems can be considered as reservoir power stations, e.g. as unit in plant groups that are dominated by storage power plants, but also include alpine run power stations.;The technology used in the dataset has an overall efficiency of 82%, more modern technologies show an overall efficiency of about 88%. The overall efficiency (current: 0,82; modern: 0,88) is composed of the efficiency of the works water channel (current: 1,00; modern: 1,00), the turbine (current: 0,87; modern: 0,91), the generator (current: 0,96; modern: 0,98) and the transformer (current: 0,98; modern: 0,99). For the calculation of the works water channel of run-of-river plants an efficiency of 100% is assumed.;The efficiency losses in turbines depend on the turbine type (Kaplan, Francis, Pelton, etc.), the turbine output and on the ratio between turbined water amount and the rated water amount. In König, examples for curve progressions of the relationship between these variables are shown. For current power plants an efficiency of 87% is assumed, more modern turbines show an efficiency of about 91%.;The efficiency of generators depends on the output, the rotation speed of the generator and the cooling system. For today’s power plants an efficiency of approximately 96% is assumed, modern generators show an efficiency of about 98%. The efficiency of transformers amounts to 98%, respectively 99%.;References:;König F., von (1985) Bau von Wasserkraftanlagen. C.F. Müller, Karlsruhe.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
This dataset has been extrapolated from an original dataset covering the geography CH (Switzerland) and valid for the time period 1945-1970. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.

The annual production volume is valid for 2009.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Sampling procedure based on literature. Some information regarding the results is given without source notes or detailed, comprehensible derivation due to the guaranteed confidential treatment of data.

flow.name: electricity, high voltage
flow.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

exchanges.description:
Estimation. To estimate the area of the water courses (i.e. the section between the water inlet and the weir) the length and average width according to the map is multiplied. As a result an index (approximate value) is calculated where the facts that hydropower plants affect natural habitats and disturb ground water are accounted for. Averaged over the investigated sample and distributed over life time the specific land use amounts to 4,5 10^-3 m2a/kWh, the transformation of land amounts to 5,6 10^-3 m2a/kWh. Thereby major rivers show lower values than small ones. 

Due to the fact that the calculated value represents an index value, it is not a hundred per cent comparable with other information relating to areas. In Switzerland the area before operation of the run-of-river plant is defined as "transformation from pasture" and "transformation from shrub land". This is because of cultivated land reclamation reasons flood protection and drainage measures have been implemented in the past. Due to the fact that it is not allowed fertilizing the area bordering the river, this land is assumed to be shrub land. Thereby, a ratio of 50 % for shrub land and 50 % for pasture is estimated. 

The area after commissioning of the run-of-river plant is defined as "transformation to river, artificial". Land use for the weir and the power station is defined as "transformation to industrial area" at which 1 % of the value is defined for the water course. Land use for access roads can be neglected because most of the power plants are built on developed land. 

It has to be pointed out that run-of-river power plants do not necessarily have a negative impact on the ecological situation (e.g. new construction of the power plant Ruppoldingen).
Estimation. Standard values for land use are assumed.
Estimation. Lifetime is assumed to be 80 years (p. 29ff); net production is assumed to be 15484 GWh/a (Tab. 1.1 p. 3).

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. It has been estimated that there is no emission to air. All the turbine water which enters the activity is released back to water.

Estimation. The lubricating oil is in a closed loop system (i.e. cannot get into the turbined water system) and is disposed annualy as waste oil in a hazardous waste treatment plant. The information given is based on own assumptions.

exchanges.description: Reflects range average to best performance.

Calculated value. With respect to the ecological importance the following has to be considered: the turbined amount of water is via physical laws related to the produced amount of electricity, i.e. the turbined amount of water does not provide independent, ecological relevant information. The specific turbined amount of water (in m3/kWh) represents a value that is inversely proportional to the average net head. However, the turbined amount of water is an ecological relevant measurement in terms of representing the water amount that is in parts detracted from the natural water cycle. With an average ned head of 10 metres the specific turbined water amount accounts for 45 m3/kWh. If this value is extrapolated to the production volumes of the run-of-river power plants in Switzerland, the overall turbined water amount would be 747x10^9 m3/a. Taking the total runoff of 53,5 10^9 m3/a of Switzerland into account the water is turbined 14 times before leaving the land. 

Standard values for resources are assumed.

flow.name: Water, turbine use, unspecified natural origin

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Data are adopted from the Swiss power plant sample as it stands, therefore uncertainty is increased. 

To estimate the area of the water courses (i.e. the section between the water inlet and the weir) the length and average width according to the map is multiplied. As a result an index (approximate value) is calculated where the facts that hydropower plants affect natural habitats and disturb ground water are accounted for. Averaged over the investigated sample and distributed over life time the specific land use amounts to 4,5 10^-3 m2a/kWh, the transformation of land amounts to 5,6 10^-3 m2a/kWh. Thereby major rivers show lower values than small ones. 

Due to the fact that the calculated value represents an index value, it is not a hundred per cent comparable with other information relating to areas. In Switzerland the area before operation of the run-of-river plant is defined as "transformation from pasture" and "transformation from shrub land". This is because of cultivated land reclamation reasons flood protection and drainage measures have been implemented in the past. Due to the fact that it is not allowed fertilizing the area bordering the river, this land is assumed to be shrub land. Thereby, a ratio of 50 % for shrub land and 50 % for pasture is estimated. 

The area after commissioning of the run-of-river plant is defined as "transformation to river, artificial". Land use for the weir and the power station is defined as "transformation to industrial area" at which 1 % of the value is defined for the water course. Land use for access roads can be neglected because most of the power plants are built on developed land. 

It has to be pointed out that run-of-river power plants do not necessarily have a negative impact on the ecological situation (e.g. new construction of the power plant Ruppoldingen).

Estimation. A consumption of lubricating oil for turbines of 9 liters per GWh is estimated. With an oil density of 0.84 kg/l this amounts to 0.007 g/kWh. The lubricating oil is in a closed loop system (i.e. cannot get into the turbined water system) and is disposed annualy as waste oil in a hazardous waste treatment plant.
